q1.value: Attributional Dynamics for Ostracism Associated with Phubbing

q3.value: How do people assign blame for phubbing, a form of ostracism caused by one person ignoring someone by using their phone? We draw on attributional theory to examine how people assign blame towards the self, the ostracizing partner, their relationship,the context, and the phone. We have conducted two pilot studies and found that people blame external factors more than the self for a negative event (being ostracized) and people blaming the phone occurs when the phone is simply present but not in use, and even when the phone is not visibly present. We plan to conduct five experimental studies to examine the attributional dynamics of phubbing. Study 1 and Study 2 will be a replicate of our pilot studies. Study 3 will explore how private vs. public social context impact the dynamics of phubbing. Study 4 will explore whether the dynamics of phubbing will apply to ten different scenarios. Study 5 will examine whether people will assign different attributions when they use different types of media.

q4.value:
Study 1 will focus on phubbers’ and phubbees’ attributional dynamics. We propose 2 hypotheses and 3 research questions. 

H1: Participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized from phubbing.
H2: Phubbees will attribute more blame to the phone than to other external causes.
RQ1: Will phubbers assign more attributions to the phone than to themselves?
RQ2: Will self-attribution, dispositional attribution, interpersonal attribution, situational attribution, and phone attribution differ between phubbees and phubbers?
RQ3: How do people make inferences about phone activities during phubbing and does it affect attributions?

Study 2 will focus on different types of phone presence conditions and the connections between phone attributions and attitudes toward the phone. We propose five hypotheses and one research question. 
H1: In the phone use condition, participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized from phubbing (replicating Study 1).
H2a: In the phone use condition, phubbees will assign more attribution to the phone than to the self, interpersonal, or situational factors.
H2b: In the phone use condition, phubbers will assign more attribution to the phone than dispositional attribution.
H3: Phubbees will assign the most phone attribution when the phone is in use, followed by when the phone is present but not in use, and when the phone is not visibly present.
RQ1: How will phubbers assign phone attributions across the three conditions of phone presence?
H4: Phone attribution will be positively associated with beliefs about the negative consequences of phone use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the phone, and support for a strict phone use regulation.

Study3 will focus on the attributional dynamics in public vs. in private settings. We propose three hypotheses.   
H1: Participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized from phubbing. 
H2: Participants will attribute more blame to the phone than to other external causes.
H3: There will be no differences in phone attributions between a public setting scenario and a private setting scenario. 

Study 4 will focus on attributional dynamics across different scenarios. We propose three hypotheses. 
H1: Participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized from phubbing.
H2: Phubbees will attribute more blame to the phone than to other external causes.
H3: Phone attribution will be positively associated with beliefs about the negative consequences of phone use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the phone, and support for a strict phone use regulation.

Study 5 will focus on the attributional dynamics in four different types of media: the phone, laptop, TV, and book. We propose five hypotheses and three research questions. 
H1: Participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized. 
H2a: In the phone condition, participants will attribute more blame to the phone than to other external causes.
H2b: In the laptop condition, participants will attribute more blame to the laptop than to other external causes.
 RQ1: In the TV and book conditions, will participants assign more blames to TV and books than to other external causes? 
RQ2: Will the dynamics of attributions differ across the four different types of media? 
H3a: Phone attribution will be positively associated with beliefs about the negative consequences of phone use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the phone, and support for a strict phone use regulation.
H3b: Laptop attribution will be positively associated with beliefs about the negative consequences of laptop use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the laptop, and support for a strict laptop use regulation.
RQ3: Will TV and book attributions impact people’s beliefs about the negative consequences of TV/book use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the TV/books, and support for a strict TV/book use regulation.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Study 1 will be a two-group between-subject design. Participants will be randomly assigned as a phubber or a phubbee.

Study 2 will be a 2 (phubbee vs. phubber) by 3 (phone use, phone present but no in use, and phone not present) between-subject design. 

Study 3 will be a 2 (phubbee vs. phubber) by 2 (public setting vs. private setting) between-subject design. 

Study 4 will be a two-group between-subject design. Participants will be randomly assigned as a phubber or a phubbee.

Study 5 will be a  2 (phubbee vs. phubber) by 4 (phone, laptop, TV, and book between-subject design.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to each condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We have conducted two pilot studies and analyzed the data. These pilot studies helped us test the main measures of the studies and preliminarily explore the attribution patterns of phubbing.

question.value: We will collect data from Mturkers through mturk.com and cloudresearch.com from Feb. 2020 to March 2020. We will recruit mturkers who have completed more than 1000 hits and who have an approval rate of 98% and above to participate in our study. We will pay participants 75 cents for participation.

q13.value: For Study 1, we anticipate recruiting around 80 participants. For Study 2, we anticipate to recruit  240 participants. For Study 3, we anticipate recruiting 160 participants. F For Study4, we anticipate recruiting 800 participants. or Study 5, we anticipate recruiting 320 participants.

q14.value: Based on our power analysis, each cell requires 31 participants. We plan to recruit 40 participants per cell in case of missing data.

question.value:
In Study1, we will manipulate phubbing. Participants will be asked to imagine themselves either as a phubber (the person who is using the phone) or as a phubbee (the person who is ostracised). 

In Study 2, we will manipulate phubbing and phone presence. Participants will be asked to imagine themselves either as a phubber (the person who is using the phone) or as a phubbee (the person who is ostracised). They will be also randomly assigned to three conditions of phone presence: Phone in use, phone is present but not in use, phone is not visibly present. 

In Study 3, we will manipulate phubbing and setting. Participants will be asked to imagine themselves either as a phubber (the person who is using the phone) or as a phubbee (the person who is ostracised). They will be randomly assigned to two setting conditions: public vs. private. 

In Study 4, we will manipulate phubbing. Participants will be asked to imagine themselves either as a phubber (the person who is using the phone) or as a phubbee (the person who is ostracised). 

In Study 5, we will manipulate phubbing and phone presence. Participants will be asked to imagine themselves either as a phubber (the person who is using the phone) or as a phubbee (the person who is ostracised). We will also measure four levels of media use: phone, laptop, TV, and book.

In all five studies, we will measure: 1. five types attributions: self, dispositional, interpersonal, situational, and phone. 2. Ostracism as a manipulation check. 3. Perceived phone/media activities. 4. demographic variable and media use variables. 
In Studies 2, 3, 4 and 5, we will measure perceived addictive framing of phone/media, perceived negative consequences of phone/media use, and phone/media use regulation.

Study 1 will focus on phubbers’ and phubbees’ attributional dynamics. We propose 2 hypotheses and 3 research questions. 

H1: Participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized from phubbing.
We will conduct a paired-sample t-test to test H1. 

H2: Phubbees will attribute more blame to the phone than to other external causes.
We will use a repeated measure ANOVA with attribution type as the repeated factor to test H2. 

RQ1: Will phubbers assign more attributions to the phone than to themselves?
We will use a repeated measure ANOVA with attribution type as the repeated factor to answer RQ1. 


RQ2: Will self-attribution, dispositional attribution, interpersonal attribution, situational attribution, and phone attribution differ between phubbees and phubbers?
We will conduct a series of independent-sample t-tests to answer RQ2. 


RQ3: How do people make inferences about phone activities during phubbing and does it affect attributions?
We will conduct a two-way ANOVA to answer RQ3. 


Study 2 will focus on different types of phone presence conditions and the connections between phone attributions and attitudes toward the phone. We propose five hypotheses and one research question. 

H1: In the phone use condition, participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized from phubbing (replicating Study 1).
We will conduct a paired-sample t-test to test H1. 


H2a: In the phone use condition, phubbees will assign more attribution to the phone than to the self, interpersonal, or situational factors.
We will use a repeated measure ANOVA with attribution type as the repeated factor to test H2. 

H2b: In the phone use condition, phubbers will assign more attribution to the phone than dispositional attribution.
We will use a repeated measure ANOVA with attribution type as the repeated factor to test H2. 

H3: Phubbees will assign the most phone attribution when the phone is in use, followed by when the phone is present but not in use, and when the phone is not visibly present.
We will use a one-way ANOVA to test H3. 

RQ1: How will phubbers assign phone attributions across the three conditions of phone presence?
We will use a one-way ANOVA to answer RQ1.  


H4: Phone attribution will be positively associated with beliefs about the negative consequences of phone use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the phone, and support for a strict phone use regulation.
We will conduct a series of hierarchical regression to test H4. 


Study3 will focus on the attributional dynamics in public vs. in private settings. We propose three hypotheses.   

H1: Participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized from phubbing. 
We will conduct a paired-sample t-test to test H1. 

H2: Participants will attribute more blame to the phone than to other external causes.
We will use a repeated measure ANOVA with attribution type as the repeated factor to test H2. 

H3: There will be no differences in phone attributions between a public setting scenario and a private setting scenario. 
We will conduct a two-way ANOVA to test H3. 



Study 4 will focus on attributional dynamics across different scenarios. We propose three hypotheses. 

H1: Participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized from phubbing.
We will conduct a paired-sample t-test to test H1. 

H2: Phubbees will attribute more blame to the phone than to other external causes.
We will use a repeated measure ANOVA with attribution type as the repeated factor to test H2. 

H3: Phone attribution will be positively associated with beliefs about the negative consequences of phone use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the phone, and support for a strict phone use regulation.
We will conduct a series of hierarchical regression to test H3. 


Study 5 will focus on the attributional dynamics in four different types of media: the phone, laptop, TV, and book. We propose five hypotheses and three research questions. 

H1: Participants will assign more external attributions than self-attributions for being socially ostracized from phubbing. 
We will conduct a paired-sample t-test to test H1. 

H2a: In the phone condition, participants will attribute more blame to the phone than to other external causes.
We will use a repeated measure ANOVA with attribution type as the repeated factor to test H2a. 

H2b: In the laptop condition, participants will attribute more blame to the laptop than to other external causes.
We will use a repeated measure ANOVA with attribution type as the repeated factor to test H2b. 

RQ1: In the TV and book conditions, will participants assign more blames to TV and books than to other external causes? 
We will use a repeated measure ANOVA with attribution type as the repeated factor to answer RQ1. 

RQ2: Will the dynamics of attributions differ across the four different types of media? 
We will use two-way ANOVA to answer RQ2. 

H3a: Phone attribution will be positively associated with beliefs about the negative consequences of phone use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the phone, and support for a strict phone use regulation.
We will conduct a series of hierarchical regression to test H3a. 


H3b: Laptop attribution will be positively associated with beliefs about the negative consequences of laptop use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the laptop, and support for a strict laptop use regulation.
We will conduct a series of hierarchical regression to test H3b. 


RQ3: Will TV and book attributions impact people’s beliefs about the negative consequences of TV/book use, beliefs of the addictive framing of the TV/books, and support for a strict TV/book use regulation.
We will conduct a series of hierarchical regression to test RQ3.

attributes.title: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Comparing Aquatic and Land Exercise on Dynamic Balance in Older Adults

q1.value: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Comparing Aquatic and Land Exercise on Dynamic Balance in Older Adults

q2.value: Youngwook Kim, Michael Nicholas Vakula, Benjamin Waller, Eadric Bressel

q3.value: Balance impairments are the leading causes of falls in older adults. Various exercise programs are provided for older adults to improve balance and reduce risks of falls. Aquatic-based exercises have been broadly practiced as a safer alternative to land-based exercises. However, there has been no systematic review with meta-analysis comparing the effects of aquatic and land exercises on dynamic balance. Therefore, the purpose of this systematic review and meta-analysis will be to compare the effectiveness of aquatic and land exercise on dynamic balance in older adults.

question.value:
The following electronic databases will be searched by one reviewer (Y.K.): PubMed, MEDLINE, CINAHL, SPORTDiscus, psycINFO. The databases will be examined using the following combination of keywords: (aquatic therapy OR aquatic activity OR aquatic aerobics OR aquaerobics OR aquatic exercise OR aquatic physical therapy OR aquatic physiotherapy OR aquatic rehabilitation OR hydrotherapy OR pool exercise* OR pool therapy OR swimming OR swimming therapy OR water aerobics OR water-based exercise OR water exercise OR water rehabilitation OR water therapy OR water rehabilitation OR water activity, OR water sport∗) AND (aged OR older OR elderly OR senior) AND (balance OR postur*). There will be no restriction on the publication year.

All articles identified in the database search will be exported to Zotero 5.0.66 (http://www.zotero.org) and any duplicates will be deleted. Two reviewers (Y.K. and M.V.) will initially screen, include, and exclude studies based on titles and abstracts. Full text of identified articles will be obtained and reviewed by the first and second reviewers (Y.K. and M.V.). Disagreements will be resolved by discussion and third (E.B.) and fourth (B.W.) reviewers will be consulted as necessary.

ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA 
1. Type of participants 
Studies that recruited adults aged 65 years or older will be included. There will be no restriction on the injury or disorder type, settings, and the history of falls. Animal studies and human studies with participants aged under 65 will be excluded. 

2. Type of studies 
Studies conducted as a randomized control trial (RCT) and published in the English language will be considered for inclusion. Studies with other research designs or non-peer-reviewed articles will be excluded. 

3. Intervention 
Studies that employed all types of aquatic exercise (AE) with a description of intervention details, such as duration, frequency, type, and intensity of AE, will be included. The studies must have included a minimum of one AE group and a comparison group participating in another exercise program on dry land. Studies that did not include exercise components, such as bath or spa therapies, will be excluded. 

4. Outcome measures 
Studies must have reported at least one outcome related to dynamic balance and compared the outcomes between AE and land exercise (LE) groups. All outcome measures must have been conducted on land because postural adjustment and movement patterns are significantly altered in water, and daily living activities are mostly performed on dry land. Studies including mixed intervention (e.g., both AE and LE in all groups) will be excluded and any studies not providing data on the baseline or end-point outcomes will be additionally excluded from the meta-analysis.

q13.value: This is a systematic review and meta-analysis of published studies. Thus, we did not need to calculate the sample size. We will include all the published studies that meet the eligibility criteria.

question.value: We will compare the effects of aquatic and land exercises on dynamic balance abilities in older adults aged 65 or older.
Any outcome measurements related to dynamic balance will be included in the systematic review and meta-analysis.

META-ANALYSIS
Outcome measurements included in the meta-analysis will be assigned into three categories: (a) dynamic steady-state balance, (b) proactive balance, and (c) balance test batteries. Where a trial reported more than one outcome in one of these categories, only one outcome with the highest priority will be used for the analysis. The highest priority will be given to the gait speed in the dynamic steady-state balance, Functional Reach Test in the dynamic steady-state balance, and the Berg Balance Scale in the balance test battery. When these representative outcomes are not available, the most similar ones about the temporal and spatial structure will be used. For a crossover RCT study, first-phase data will be used. Sensitivity analyses will be additionally performed to figure out the differences in outcomes when removing one trial with a clearly different direction of change in each category of balance outcome measurements.  

The effect sizes between AE and LE groups will be described as standardized mean differences (SMD) and 95% confidence intervals (CI). An effect size (SMD) 0.2-0.5, 0.5-0.8, and >0.8 will be considered a small, moderate, and large effect, respectively. In case of a lower score indicating better performance in dynamic balance, scale directions will be adjusted by multiplying -1 to data, which will result in a positive value indicating an improvement in favor of AE. For all analyses, we will use an inverse-variance weighted random-effects model. All meta-analyses will be performed using the Cochrane Collaboration’s Review Manager Software (RevMan 5.3.).

q20.value:
DATA EXTRACTION AND CODING 
All the potential studies meeting the eligibility criteria will be reviewed and coded in REDCap (https://www.project-redcap.org/). All relevant information will be extracted for each study as follows: (1) report characteristics (2) participants (3) AE settings (4) interventions (5) outcome measures (6) results. The included studies will be assessed and coded independently by two reviewers (Y.K. and M.V.) and discussed for consensus. If there is a disagreement, the study will be re-evaluated to achieve consensus.

q24.value: The analysis of the methodological quality and risk of bias of the included studies will be conducted using the Cochrane risk of bias tool (RoB 22) independently by two authors (Y.K. and M.V.). The tool can be utilized to assess the impact of each potential source of bias, at the “low”, “high”, and “somewhat concerns” risk level, respectively. The following criteria that potentially affect the risk of bias will be addressed: randomization process, deviation from intended interventions, missing outcome data, measurement of outcome, selection of the reported result, and overall bias. Any disagreements will be discussed until consensus is reached and additionally arbitrated by the third (E.B.) and fourth (B.W.) reviewers if needed.

attributes.title: The Relationship Between Uncinate Fasciculus Integrity and Daily Emotional Experiences
attributes.description: The Uncinate Fasciculus (UF) is a white matter tract in the brain that connects the amygdala, which is involved in initial processing of emotional material, and the prefrontal cortex (PFC), which plays a role in emotion regulation. Given its anatomical location and findings that depression is linked to less UF structural integrity (de Kwaasteniet et al., 2013; Taylor, MacFall, Gerig, & Krishnan, 2007;  Zhang et al., 2012), the UF has been implicated in emotional stability. UF integrity has also been linked to how quickly people respond to emotional provocation in the laboratory (Pedersen et al., 2020), where greater UF integrity was related to quicker recovery after viewing negative images as measured via facial EMG. The present project will examine how UF integrity relates to emotion experienced outside of the laboratory in daily life.

question10b.value:
Details of Larger Study
     All information regarding the larger MIDUS study procedure and data collection can be found here and inform the following sections: https://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/ICPSR/studies/37094. Below is information regarding the key variables of interest. 

MIDUS Refresher Daily Diary project
     During one subproject of MIDUS, participants took part in a daily diary study. Each day for 8 consecutive days participants reported the events and their emotions of that day over the phone. Participants reported how much they felt each of 27 emotions (13 positive and 14 negative), which will be averaged within valence for each day and across the entire study period. They also reported stressors that had occurred in the past 24 hours using the semi-structured Daily Inventory of Stressful Events49. For each day, it was noted whether a participant experienced a stressor, how many stressors they experienced, what kind of stressor they encountered (out of 7 possible events, such as having an argument or having a stressful event at work), how severe they rated each stressor, and the negative emotions they experienced as a result of the stressor.

MIDUS Refresher Neuroscience project
     A subset of the participants who completed the diary study also completed the neuroscience project within MIDUS. MRI scanning occurred on a 3-Tesla MR750 General Electric scanner (Waukesha, WI) using an 8-channel head coil. Diffusion weighted images were collected using a Stejskal-Tanner (Stejskal & Tanner, 1965) diffusion prepared single-shot echo-planar imaging pulse sequence. Sixty-five axial slices of 2 mm thickness were acquired with 6 diffusion-encoding directions at b = 400 s/mm2 and 70 diffusion encoding directions at b=1200 s/mm2, in addition to 4 baseline images (b=0 s/mm2). Images were acquired with an in-plane matrix of 128 mm × 128 mm, resulting in a 2 mm × 2 mm resolution (FOV=256 mm, TR=7000 ms, TE=68.7 ms, partial Fourier [62.5%], ASSET [SENSE] × 2). 
     The software package MRtrix3 ( v. 3.0; Tournier et al., 2019) was used to denoise the data, and correct Gibbs ringing artifacts. The FMRIB Software Library (FSL v. 5.0.11) ‘eddy’ tool was used to correct for eddy current-induced distortions and subject movements (Andersson & Sotiropoulos, 2016), as well as to skull-strip the data (Smith, 2002). Weighted least squares was used to fit the tensors at each voxel using the Diffusion Imaging In Python package (v. 0.14.0; Garyfallidis et al., 2014). The Advanced Normalization Tools software package (v. 2.2.0; Avants, Tustison, & Song, 2009) was used to create a study specific FA template, and to normalize each participant’s images to this template. Tensors from individual subjects were reoriented to preserve the principal orientations (which is important for tractography) when spatially transforming to the template, and a population-averaged tensor template was generated using the reoriented tensor maps using the Diffusion Tensor Imaging ToolKit (v. 2.3.3; Zhang, Yushkevich, Rueckert, & Gee, 2007). A mask of voxels in the FA template with values greater than 0.2 was used as a seed to compute whole-brain brain tractography using the Camino Diffusion MRI Toolkit (v. r1205; Cook et al., 2006). 
     Tracts were defined selecting only fibers passing through given ROIs (known as AND ROIs). UF were created using two AND ROIs, a coronal plane in the prefrontal cortex, and a coronal plane in the anterior temporal lobe, in the same slice as the anterior amygdala (Figure 2). A coronal plane covering the entire slice intersecting with the anterior pons served as a NOT ROI to remove fibers that extended too far posterior to be considered uncinate fasciculus.

question1a.value:
*All hypotheses involve adjusting for whole-brain FA and relevant covariates (age, gender, and for #3 and #4 an individual’s average number of stressors. 
1) Greater UF FA will be related to:
     a. higher average levels of PA
     b. lower average levels of NA
2) Greater UF FA will be related to:
     a. Less variability in PA (lower PAiSD)
     b. Less variability in NA (lower NAiSD)
3) Greater UF FA will be related to lower reactivity to daily stressors as indicated by:
     a. Less of a difference in PA on stressor days (coded 1) compared to non-stressor days (coded 0)
     b. Less of a difference in NA on stressor days (coded 1) compared to non-stressor days (coded 0)
4) Greater UF FA will be related to quicker recovery from daily stressors as indicated by:
     a. Compared to non-stressor days that follow a non-stressor day (coded 0 0), non-stressor days that follow a stressor day (coded 1 0) will have less of a decrease in PA.  
     b. Compared to non-stressor days that follow a non-stressor day (coded 0 0),  non-stressor days that follow a stressor day (coded 1 0) will have less of an increase in NA.

question2a.value:
3a-b. On stressor days, we expect that PA will be lower and NA will be higher than on non-stressor days. We expect that greater UF FA will buffer this relationship. So greater UF FA will be related to smaller differences in PA and NA on stressor vs. non-stressor days. 

4a-b. On days following a stressor, we expect that PA will be lower and NA will be higher than on days following a non-stressor day. We expect that greater UF FA will buffer this relationship. So greater FA will be related to smaller differences in PA and NA on stressor-previous vs. non-stressor-previous days.

question5a.value: The Uncinate Fasciculus (UF) is a white matter tract in the brain that connects the amygdala, which is involved in initial processing of emotional material, and the prefrontal cortex (PFC), which plays a role in emotion regulation. Given its anatomical location and findings that depression is linked to less UF structural integrity (de Kwaasteniet et al., 2013; Taylor, MacFall, Gerig, & Krishnan, 2007;  Zhang et al., 2012), the UF has been implicated in emotional stability. UF integrity has also been linked to how quickly people respond to emotional provocation in the laboratory (Pedersen et al., 2020), where greater UF integrity was related to quicker recovery after viewing negative images as measured via facial EMG. The present project will examine how UF integrity relates to emotion experienced outside of the laboratory in daily life.

registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question6c: Given 4 hypothesis tests within valence (4 positive and 4 negative), p-values will be compared to a Bonferroni corrected value of .05/4 = .0125 to adjust for multiple tests.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Details of Larger Study
     All information regarding the larger MIDUS study procedure and data collection can be found here and inform the following sections: https://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/ICPSR/studies/37094. Below is information regarding the key variables of interest. 

MIDUS Refresher Daily Diary project
     During one subproject of MIDUS, participants took part in a daily diary study. Each day for 8 consecutive days participants reported the events and their emotions of that day over the phone. Participants reported how much they felt each of 27 emotions (13 positive and 14 negative), which will be averaged within valence for each day and across the entire study period. They also reported stressors that had occurred in the past 24 hours using the semi-structured Daily Inventory of Stressful Events49. For each day, it was noted whether a participant experienced a stressor, how many stressors they experienced, what kind of stressor they encountered (out of 7 possible events, such as having an argument or having a stressful event at work), how severe they rated each stressor, and the negative emotions they experienced as a result of the stressor.

MIDUS Refresher Neuroscience project
     A subset of the participants who completed the diary study also completed the neuroscience project within MIDUS. MRI scanning occurred on a 3-Tesla MR750 General Electric scanner (Waukesha, WI) using an 8-channel head coil. Diffusion weighted images were collected using a Stejskal-Tanner (Stejskal & Tanner, 1965) diffusion prepared single-shot echo-planar imaging pulse sequence. Sixty-five axial slices of 2 mm thickness were acquired with 6 diffusion-encoding directions at b = 400 s/mm2 and 70 diffusion encoding directions at b=1200 s/mm2, in addition to 4 baseline images (b=0 s/mm2). Images were acquired with an in-plane matrix of 128 mm × 128 mm, resulting in a 2 mm × 2 mm resolution (FOV=256 mm, TR=7000 ms, TE=68.7 ms, partial Fourier [62.5%], ASSET [SENSE] × 2). 
     The software package MRtrix3 ( v. 3.0; Tournier et al., 2019) was used to denoise the data, and correct Gibbs ringing artifacts. The FMRIB Software Library (FSL v. 5.0.11) ‘eddy’ tool was used to correct for eddy current-induced distortions and subject movements (Andersson & Sotiropoulos, 2016), as well as to skull-strip the data (Smith, 2002). Weighted least squares was used to fit the tensors at each voxel using the Diffusion Imaging In Python package (v. 0.14.0; Garyfallidis et al., 2014). The Advanced Normalization Tools software package (v. 2.2.0; Avants, Tustison, & Song, 2009) was used to create a study specific FA template, and to normalize each participant’s images to this template. Tensors from individual subjects were reoriented to preserve the principal orientations (which is important for tractography) when spatially transforming to the template, and a population-averaged tensor template was generated using the reoriented tensor maps using the Diffusion Tensor Imaging ToolKit (v. 2.3.3; Zhang, Yushkevich, Rueckert, & Gee, 2007). A mask of voxels in the FA template with values greater than 0.2 was used as a seed to compute whole-brain brain tractography using the Camino Diffusion MRI Toolkit (v. r1205; Cook et al., 2006). 
     Tracts were defined selecting only fibers passing through given ROIs (known as AND ROIs). UF were created using two AND ROIs, a coronal plane in the prefrontal cortex, and a coronal plane in the anterior temporal lobe, in the same slice as the anterior amygdala (Figure 2). A coronal plane covering the entire slice intersecting with the anterior pons served as a NOT ROI to remove fibers that extended too far posterior to be considered uncinate fasciculus.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
- day-level PA: average ratings of 13 positive emotion items 
- day-level NA: average ratings of 14 negative emotion items
- Uncinate fasciculus fractional anisotropy (UFFA): see methods for how this measure was extracted
- whole-brain FA: see methods for how this measure was extracted
- age
- gender

- Dependent variable: day-level PA or day-level NA
- Independent variable: UF FA
- Covariates: whole-brain FA, age, gender

whole-brain FA is used to ensure results are not driven by overall differences in an individual's whole-brain white matter structural integrity, just the structural integrity of the Uncinate Fasciculus. 

Age and gender are often related to differences in reports of emotion.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi:
- day-level PA: average ratings of 13 positive emotion items 
- day-level NA: average ratings of 14 negative emotion items
- StressorDay: whether or not a stressor was experienced that day (0 or 1)
- Uncinate fasciculus fractional anisotropy (UFFA): see methods for how this measure was extracted
- StressorDay*UFFA
- whole-brain FA: see methods for how this measure was extracted
- age
- gender
- AvgNumStressors: average number of stressors the individual reported experiencing

- Dependent variable: day-level PA or day-level NA
- Independent variable: UF FA, StressorDay, StressorDay*UFFA
- Covariates: whole-brain FA, age, gender, AvgNumStressors

whole-brain FA is used to ensure results are not driven by overall differences in an individual's whole-brain white matter structural integrity, just the structural integrity of the Uncinate Fasciculus. 

Age and gender are often related to differences in reports of emotion. 

A person's average number of stressors are included to ensure that results aren't being influenced by the fact that some people have more stressor exposure than others. For example, someone might experience 5 stressors and another experience just 1. Both would be coded as having experienced a stressor, but this covariate adjusts for the fact that the first person is exposed to more stressors on average.

A total of 49 participants (23 males, 26 females) have daily diary and DTI data.
Sample will be based on available data.
Data is already collected and sample is already determined. Recruitment was carried out by the broader MIDUS team.

- day-level PA: average ratings of 13 positive emotion items 
- day-level NA: average ratings of 14 negative emotion items
- PreviousStressorDay: whether or not the previous day had a stressor (0 or 1)
- Uncinate fasciculus fractional anisotropy (UFFA): see methods for how this measure was extracted
- whole-brain FA: see methods for how this measure was extracted
- age
- gender
- AvgNumStressors: average number of stressors the individual reported experiencing

Potential covariate:
StressorDay: Whether the current day includes a stressor will also be considered. Either only non-stressor current days will be used in analyses or whether the current day includes a stressor or not will be included in the model.

- Dependent variables: day-level PA or day-level NA
- Independent variables: UFFA, PreviousStressorDay, PreviousStressorDay*UFFA
- Covariates: whole-brain FA, age, gender, AvgStressors
- Potential Covariate: StressorDay (if not used as a covariate, only non-stressor current days will be used in this analysis.

whole-brain FA is used to ensure results are not driven by overall differences in an individual's whole-brain white matter structural integrity, just the structural integrity of the Uncinate Fasciculus. 

Age and gender are often related to differences in reports of emotion. 

A person's average number of stressors are included to ensure that results aren't being influenced by the fact that some people have more stressor exposure than others. For example, someone might experience 5 stressors and another experience just 1. Both would be coded as having experienced a stressor, but this covariate adjusts for the fact that the first person is exposed to more stressors on average.

- age
- gender

- Covariates: whole-brain FA, age, gender

whole-brain FA is used to ensure results are not driven by overall differences in an individual's whole-brain white matter structural integrity, just the structural integrity of the Uncinate Fasciculus. 

Age and gender are often related to differences in reports of emotion.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
persons with metallic implants, such as prostheses or aneurysm clips
persons with electronic implants, such as cardiac pacemakers
pregnant women
persons with neurological problems, such as seizure disorders (e.g., epilepsy), Parkinson’s disease, tremors, multiple sclerosis, Alzheimer’s disease, history of stroke or head injury

summary.value:
---
title: "Pre-Registration LAB2.0 Machine Learning"
author: "Erin M. Buchanan"
date: "2/7/2020"
output: html_document
---

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```

## Background

The Linguistic Annotated Bibliography (LAB; Buchanan, Valentine, & Maxwell, 2019) is a resource for all types of researchers who want to know what stimuli, corpora, and tools are available for use in their studies. The LAB currently has ~800 listings and the real problem of continuing to grow in a way difficult to manage manually. Therefore, we wish to implement a semi-automated process to help find, select, and enter data into the LAB.

## Previous Work

For the Society for Computers in Psychology, we presented details about previous work on this idea (see folders 06.presentation and 03.classification). In our previous exploration, we examined several machine learning algorithms with a bag of words input into the model and a neural net model. However, this process seemed somewhat randomly generated, using techniques each researcher felt most comfortable with. This pre-registration is to take a systematic approach to finding the best predictive algorithm for our task.

## Data Processing and Split

You can read about the selection process for articles in our readme file for the GitHub folder (https://github.com/doomlab/LAB2). The data was cleaned by:

  - Removing non-Latin symbols
  - Removing the word "keywords" from the keywords section
  - Lower-casing all words for normalization
  - Expanding contractions
  - Removing a list of stopwords (the `SMART` list from the `tm` package)
  - Removing punctuation, numbers, and extra white space
  - There is also a stemmed dataset, but we will use the full data, as stemming may create unusual words given the context of the text (scientific abstracts)
  - Additionally, we did not spell check the data, given we expect many words to be found as "misspelled" due to science specific topics, and generally abstracts should be correctly spelled

We split this data into:

  - Training: all data before 2019
    - We will further split this data into 90-10 split to train and development test our algorithms
  - Testing: all data after 2019
    - We will use this data to examine accuracy, precision, and recall as a second test for model selection

In our previous examinations, we originally separated out the LRE data as a separate test. It was found that models needed training on LRE type abstracts to be accurate at predicting LRE articles, and therefore, we combined data into pre and post 2019. The split on 2019 was chosen simply because of when the original LAB was compiled. 

## Next Steps

There are two main components one can change in our process to create a predictive algorithm: 

- The features extracted for input into a machine learning algorithm
- The machine learning algorithm

Therefore, we will manipulate both of these variables.

### Machine Learning Algorithms

We will use the follow algorithms as popular selections for a classification task:

- Logistic regression with the following setup from Python and `sklearn`:

```{python eval = F}
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression
from sklearn.metrics import classification_report
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score

lr = LogisticRegression(penalty='l2', solver='lbfgs', multi_class='ovr',
                        max_iter=10000, C=1, random_state=42)
```

- Naive Bayes model:

```{python eval = F}
from sklearn.naive_bayes import MultinomialNB

mnb = MultinomialNB(alpha=1)
```

- Support Vector Machine:

```{python eval = F}
from sklearn.svm import LinearSVC

svm = LinearSVC(penalty='l2', C=1, random_state=42)
```

### Input Feature Matrix

We will use the following input feature matrices as options:

- Simple bag of words frequency counts: a term by document matrix with frequency counts as numeric values

```{python eval = F}
from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import CountVectorizer

cv = CountVectorizer(binary=False, #not true false, actual counts
                    min_df=0.0, #min proportion words have to occur to be included
                    max_df=1.0, #max proportion 
                    decode_error='replace') #take out bad bytes
```

- The bag of words method with a Term-Frequency Inverse Document Frequency normalizer applied to it

```{python eval = F}
from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import TfidfVectorizer

tv = TfidfVectorizer(use_idf=True, min_df=0.0, max_df=1.0)
```

In these two models, we will manipulate the size of the vocabulary as an input into the matrix. We will calculate the frequency of tokens found in the training text, as shown below.

```{r}
library(tidytext)
library(dplyr)
text_data <- read.csv("../02.data/output_data/complete_processed_data_no_stem.csv", stringsAsFactors = F)

tokens <- text_data %>% 
  unnest_tokens(word, text) 

counts <- tokens %>% count(word, sort = T)
nrow(counts)
counts$percent <- counts$n / nrow(counts) * 100

sum(counts$percent > .05)
```
There are approximately 20,000 words in this data. We will start with the top 100 words and increase in units of 100 for matrix size up to 4000 words (which accounts for approximately .05% of word occurrence ~ 10 mentions across all articles).

- A Latent Semantic Analysis space, which uses Singular Vector Decomposition to transform a term by document matrix into a vector space model

```{python eval = F}
from gensim import corpora
from gensim.models import LsiModel
from gensim.models.coherencemodel import CoherenceModel

#create a dictionary of the words
dictionary = corpora.Dictionary(processed_text)

#create a TDM
doc_term_matrix = [dictionary.doc2bow(doc) for doc in processed_text]

lsamodel = LsiModel(doc_term_matrix, 
           num_topics=VARIABLE, 
           id2word = dictionary)

V = gensim.matutils.corpus2dense(lsamodel[doc_term_matrix], len(lsamodel.projection.s)).T / lsamodel.projection.s
```

- A Topics Model, which uses Latent Dirichlet Allocation to transform a term by document matrix into a vector space model

```{python eval = F}
from gensim.models import LdaModel
lda_model = LdaModel(corpus = doc_term_matrix, #TDM
                              id2word = dictionary, #Dictionary
                              num_topics = VARIABLE,
                              random_state = 100)
DT = lda_model[doc_term_matrix]
DT = gensim.matutils.corpus2csc(DT)
#DT.T.toarray() if the sparse matrix doesn't compute
```

On all of these models, the number of dimensions can be manipulated to input into the algorithm. We will use the same rules as above - varying the number of dimensions starting at 100 and increasing in units of 100 until we reach 4000 dimensions. 

- A Word2Vec model, which is a shallow neural net model. We will use the following function to export the Word2Vec vectors from the model. 

```{python eval = F}
from gensim.models import Word2Vec
w2v_model = Word2Vec(tokenized_train, #corpus of tokenized words
            size=VARIABLE, #number of features
            window=VARIABLE, #size of moving window
            min_count=1, #minimum number of times word has to be seen 
            sg = 0, #cbow model
            iter=5, workers=5) #iterations and cores
            
#create flattening function
def document_vectorizer(corpus, model, num_features):
    vocabulary = set(model.wv.index2word)
    
    def average_word_vectors(words, model, vocabulary, num_features):
        feature_vector = np.zeros((num_features,), dtype="float64")
        nwords = 0.
        
        for word in words:
            if word in vocabulary: 
                nwords = nwords + 1.
                feature_vector = np.add(feature_vector, model.wv[word])
        if nwords:
            feature_vector = np.divide(feature_vector, nwords)

        return feature_vector

    features = [average_word_vectors(tokenized_sentence, model, vocabulary, num_features)
                    for tokenized_sentence in corpus]
    return np.array(features)
```

- A FastText Model, which is an updated version of Word2Vec, which should improve with more idiosyncratic text

```{python eval = F}
from gensim.models.fasttext import FastText

ft_model = FastText(tokenized_train, 
                    size=VARIABLE, 
                    window=VARIABLE,
                    sg = 0,
                    min_count=1, 
                    iter=5, workers=4)
```

In both of these models, there are several facets to manipulate:

- size: the number of dimensions, starting at 100, increasing by 100, up to 4000
- window: the size of the moving window, which we will vary from 3 words to 10 words (see http://crr.ugent.be/papers/Mandera_et_al_JML_2016.pdf)
- CBOW versus Skip-Gram, both model types will be estimated

Other models of language representation were considered (HAL, BEAGLE), but these were not easily programmed and their core conceptual underpinnings are captured in one or more of these other models. 

## Stopping Rule

With each of the increases of dimensionality, we will stop running models if:

- Minimally, we expect to run 100 to 1000 as our dimensionality with increases up to 4000 except:
  - Too big to compute
  - Accuracy, precision, recall do not increase by 1%, which is our model selection rule listed below

## Picking a Model

The model with the highest accuracy, recall, and precision for each class (included, not included) will be selected. In the case of models within +/- 1% of these statistics (a tie of models who all present values in the same range), we will use the simplest technique:

- In order simple to complex: logistic regression, naive bayes, support vector machines
- Order: bag of words, tf-idf, LSA, Topics, Word2Vec, FastText (although this order can be somewhat arbitrary for models of the same type, the "older" model was chosen as simpler)

This selection will be calculated across the testing development set, as well as the extension testing set of new articles. 

## A comparison point

One of the authors additionally programmed this model using a deep learning technique: a hybrid recurrent - convolutional neural net model with multiple layers. We will include this model in supplemental materials and examine how it compares to simpler approaches to classification. Because these models include many points of manipulation, we will use the model as-is from the expert, to demonstrate if the added complexity is necessary for prediction. Given our previous exploration, we believe simpler models will perform as well as the deep learning model; however, if it outperforms the simpler models, we will note this point in our paper and use this model as our prediction technique. 

## Follow up to classification

Once this model is selected, we will calculate the probability of inclusion (i.e. predict cases) for the entire dataset and use a ROC analysis to find a "cut-off" score for inclusion. We expect that a 50/50 probability will classify well, however, this analysis may give us a more sensitive score for including articles, rather than the 50/50 split normally employed by algorithms. This score will also allow us to potentially determine a "gray" area range for articles that should be voted on by crowd sourcing or examined more closely (i.e., by a human).

## Updating the model

We will have to manually enter each item into the LAB to complete the total coding scheme. Because of this human intervention, we can weed out incorrect "included" classifications from the model. We will update the final selected model with new data after new articles are entered into the lab and articles are excluded. This update ensures that new trends and article writing styles are captured for future prediction.

The model with the highest accuracy, recall, and precision for each class (included, not included) will be selected. In the case of models within +/- 1% of these statistics (a tie of models who all present values in the same range), we will use the simplest technique:

- In order simple to complex: logistic regression, naive bayes, support vector machines
- Order: bag of words, tf-idf, LSA, Topics, Word2Vec, FastText (although this order can be somewhat arbitrary for models of the same type, the "older" model was chosen as simpler)

This selection will be calculated across the testing development set, as well as the extension testing set of new articles. 

## A comparison point

One of the authors additionally programmed this model using a deep learning technique: a hybrid recurrent - convolutional neural net model with multiple layers. We will include this model in supplemental materials and examine how it compares to simpler approaches to classification. Because these models include many points of manipulation, we will use the model as-is from the expert, to demonstrate if the added complexity is necessary for prediction. Given our previous exploration, we believe simpler models will perform as well as the deep learning model; however, if it outperforms the simpler models, we will note this point in our paper and use this model as our prediction technique. 

## Follow up to classification

Once this model is selected, we will calculate the probability of inclusion (i.e. predict cases) for the entire dataset and use a ROC analysis to find a "cut-off" score for inclusion. We expect that a 50/50 probability will classify well, however, this analysis may give us a more sensitive score for including articles, rather than the 50/50 split normally employed by algorithms. This score will also allow us to potentially determine a "gray" area range for articles that should be voted on by crowd sourcing or examined more closely (i.e., by a human).

## Updating the model

We will have to manually enter each item into the LAB to complete the total coding scheme. Because of this human intervention, we can weed out incorrect "included" classifications from the model. We will update the final selected model with new data after new articles are entered into the lab and articles are excluded. This update ensures that new trends and article writing styles are captured for future prediction.

attributes.title: Lifestyle Interventions for Cancer Survivors and Supporters During Survivorship: A Scoping Review
attributes.description: Due to advances in research and treatment, the population of cancer survivors is increasing and people are living longer after a diagnosis. Thus, attention to the health and well being of this survivor population is critical. This review will summarize the characteristics and outcomes of lifestyle interventions for adult post-treatment cancer survivors and supporter persons (i.e., family members).
attributes.withdrawal_justification: Error(s) in the registration, will be re-submitting the registration after eliminating all errors and careful examination of registration' contents.

attributes.title: Dopamine genetics and metabolism as predictors of impulse control behaviour

summary.value:
Summary:
The use of dopamine agonists (DA) is a common form of dopamine replacement therapy for Parkinson’s disease (PD). Unfortunately, this type of medication can lead to impulse control disorders (ICDs) in approximately 14-40% of people who take it (Weintraub et al., 2010; Bastiaens et al., 2013; Erga et al., 2018). There is currently no reliable way to identify those at risk of developing ICDs and their damaging side effects. These side effects include, but are not limited to, pathological gambling, compulsive shopping, binge eating and hypersexuality. Dopamine levels in the brain are under the influence of many complex factors, including genetics. Previous studies have identified a dopamine genetic risk score (DGRS) as a possible method to quantify genetic influences on central dopamine transmission, based upon natural mutations within 5 key dopaminergic genes (DRD1, DRD2, DRD3, COMT and DAT) (Pearson-Fuhrhop et al., 2013 & 2014 MacDonald et al., 2016). Mutations within these genes are given a score dependent on whether they act to either increase (1) or decrease (0) central dopamine transmission, resulting in an overall DGRS of 0-5 (higher score = greater dopamine transmission). This DGRS has previously been utilised to determine relationships between dopamine neurotransmission and cortical plasticity (Pearson-Fuhrhop et al., 2013) or depression (Pearson-Fuhrhop et al., 2014). Of most relevance to the current study, the DGRS has predicted the effect of DA medication on impulse control behaviour recorded during laboratory-based tasks in healthy older adults of typical age for PD onset (MacDonald et al., 2016). It was found that participants with a higher DGRS had better impulse control at baseline (with no DA medication) than those with a lower DGRS. Although interestingly, participants with a higher score showed impulse control impairments following DA administration, whereas medication improved impulse control for individuals with a lower DGRS. These results reflect the current thinking that the relationship between impulse control and dopamine neurotransmission identified by the DGRS, can be visualised as an inverted-U. According to this relationship, ICDs would be seen when people are shifted (e.g. by dopamine medication) beyond the apex of the curve.

The current study seeks to answer two research questions relating to the inverted-U theory mentioned above. It is not yet known whether the same divergent relationship between dopamine genetics, medication and impulse control exists in younger healthy adults. Therefore, a worthwhile first question to ask is whether the relationship exists in younger healthy adults at baseline, without any medication, and thereby examine the pure genetic effect on dopamine neurotransmission and behaviour. By comparing this relationship between younger and older healthy adults we can not only elucidate the role of healthy aging, but thereby also isolate any further changes observed as a result of disease mechanisms and dopamine medication in people with PD.

Secondly, previous work with the DGRS has assumed a direct link between levels of dopamine neurotransmission and the DGRS. Our second research question is therefore to ask whether this critical link exists between genetic polymorphisms and central dopamine levels by including measures of dopamine metabolism. We cannot directly measure dopamine transmission in widespread neural networks, but we currently predict this neurotransmission via genetic variation (DGRS) and will now investigate whether our DGRS prediction matches with biochemical measures of central dopamine activity. In humans, homovanillic acid in blood plasma (pHVA) is considered one of the most direct methods to assess widespread activity of dopamine neurons. Conversion to pHVA is the only metabolic route for dopamine and therefore total body pHVA measured in the blood will reflect neuronal dopamine release and metabolism. This measure is therefore an ideal tool to use in an initial proof-of-concept study to investigate how genetic mutations affect dopamine neurotransmission.


Aims: 
1)	To investigate whether behavioural measures of impulse control are significantly different between healthy younger adults with a higher versus lower DGRS.
2)	To investigate whether levels of dopamine metabolism (i.e. pHVA concentrations) are significantly different between healthy younger adults with a higher versus lower DGRS.


Hypotheses:
1)	A higher DGRS will be associated with better objective and subjective measures of impulse control (i.e. less impulsivity) compared to a lower DGRS.
2)	Participants with the higher DGRS (i.e. higher levels of dopamine transmission) will have higher concentrations of pHVA in their blood compared to participants with the lower DGRS.


Protocol:
During visit one (screening), participants will provide a saliva sample which will be sent to LGC Genomics for DNA analysis and genotyping for the 5 genes that make up the DGRS (DRD1, DRD2, DRD3, COMT and DAT). Specific mutations within these genes will determine each individual’s DGRS, as outlined in the summary.

Screening will allow the recruitment of 60 participants who are identified following genetic analysis to have a higher and lower DGRS (30 in each group). Participants will be between the ages of 18-40 and will not be taking any medications which could affect levels of dopamine, e.g. Ritalin. Each participant will then provide a blood sample on three separate occasions for analysis of average pHVA concentration. Participants will be told to i) avoid foods high in monoamine and flavonoid content for 24 hours prior to blood collection, ii) keep their diet consistent in the 24 hours prior to each session which will be assessed with a food diary, and iii) arrive for the session after an over-night fast. Fasting blood samples (6ml) will be collected by a trained phlebotomist via venepuncture from the antecubital vein while participants remain in a semi-supine position.

In addition to the blood samples, across their three visits, participants will complete three laboratory-based behavioural tasks. These behavioural tasks require the participants to be in a seated position, while they respond to stimuli on a computer screen using their index finger(s). The first behavioural task is the bimanual Anticipatory Response Inhibition (ARI) task (Coxon et al., 2007) which requires participants to make two rising bars on the computer screen intercept a stationary target by releasing their index fingers from two mechanical switches. Participants are occasionally required to inhibit this release response when the bars stop rising at random before the target. This task measures response inhibition, the motor component of impulse control. The second behavioural task is the Gambling task, this is a decisional impulsivity task (Verbruggen et al ,2019; Eben et al., preprint) which tests decision making, the cognitive component of impulse control. In this task, participants aim to win as many points as possible when picking between two presented pie charts. The first pie chart has a 100% guarantee of winning the amount of points in the pie chart. The second pie chart represents a choice between receiving nothing or winning a higher amount of points, however this probability varies and poses a greater risk of receiving nothing. The third behavioural task is the Balloon Analogue Risk Task (BART) which produces a measure of risk taking behaviour (also a cognitive component of impulse control). Participants are presented with a balloon and two options. Option one allows them to incrementally pump up the balloon. With each pump they build the potential monetary reward for that balloon, but also increase the chance of the balloon randomly popping and losing any money built up in that trial. This means that with each pump there is greater risk but also greater potential reward. Option 2 allows the participant to permanently bank the money they have won at any time before the balloon pops. A simple 7-point scale will record motivation levels for each cognitive task to control for motivation as a potential confound.

Participants will also complete three questionnaires to record subjective, real-world measures of impulse control: The Questionnaire for Impulsive-Compulsive disorders in PD short version (QUIP-short), QUIP rating scale (QUIP-RS) and the Barratt Impulsiveness scale. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment will control for general cognitive function as a potential confound.


Data analysis:
Genotyping:
Genotyping will be conducted for the five genes making up the DGRS (DRD1, DRD2, DRD3, COMT and DAT). For each gene, the presence or absence of a specific mutation which is predicted to either increase or decrease central dopamine transmission will result in a score of 1 or 0 for that gene, respectively. Scores for each gene will be added together and each participant will therefore receive an initial non-weighted overall score between 0 and 5. Participants will then be placed into either a higher or lower DGRS group. A weighted DGRS will also be calculated using a partial least squares method, as done previously (Pearson-Fuhrhop et al., 2013, MacDonald et al., 2016).

Anticipatory Response Inhibition task:
The primary dependent measure of the ARI task is stop signal reaction time, as it signifies the efficacy and latency of the inhibition process of response inhibition. Lift times, bar stop time and percentage of successful trials will also be measured.

Gambling task:
The primary dependent measure is the difference in startRT after a gambled ‘loss’ versus after a gambled or non-gambled win. The startRT is defined as the time between the outcome of a trial and the start of a new trial as initiated by the subject (this decision itself does not lead to a reward or loss). This measure reflects a speeded, impulsive decision which can also be analysed as a function of win probability. Additionally, the proportion and speed of gamble choices will be measured for each participant and as a function of win probability and prior trial outcome.

Balloon Analogue Risk task:
The primary dependent measure for the BART is the number of balloon pumps when there is a successful collection of monetary reward. Additional measures include the number of balloon pumps when there is a successful collection of monetary reward following a trial when there is a loss (the balloon bursts and no money is rewarded) versus following a trial when there is a win (monetary reward is collected).

The Questionnaire for Impulsive-Compulsive disorders in PD:
The QUIP-short is dependent on current behaviours lasting the previous 4 weeks. Participants receive a score of 0-13 depending on whether they answer ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ to experiencing specific impulsive or compulsive behaviours. The QUIP-RS is also dependent on current behaviours lasting the previous 4 weeks, these scores are rated from 0-4 depending on the frequency of the impulsive or compulsive behaviour (never, rarely, sometimes, often, very often). Participants receive an overall score between 0-96.

Barratt Impulsiveness scale: 
Participants score 30 questions relating to real-world behaviours on a 4-point scale (Rarely/Never, Occasionally, Often, Almost Always/Always), therefore receiving an overall score between 0-120. The higher the overall score, the higher a person’s level of impulsiveness.

The Montreal Cognitive Assessment:
Participants receive a score out of 30 for completing various cognitive tasks. A normal score is equal to or greater than 26.

Venepuncture:
Blood samples will be processed immediately following venepuncture by centrifuging the EDTA tube for 10 minutes, at 2000 rpm, 8oC. Plasma samples will be kept in a -80oC freezer until analysis with an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) kit. The pHVA curve will be calculated based on the standard calibration curve according to the kit manual.

Statistical analysis:
Mixed effects regression models will be used to explore associations between an individual’s DGRS (independent variable) and behavioural measures of impulse control (dependent variables). Factors such as age, Montreal Cognitive Assessment score and motivation will be controlled for by inclusion in the model as covariates. Simple linear regression will be used to determine associations between impulse control measures and i) QUIP and ii) Barratt scores. Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium of genotypes will be assessed using Chi squared tests. An independent samples t-test will be used to test for a difference in average pHVA concentration between DGRS groups. The test will be one-tailed as we have a strong prior hypothesis that individuals with a higher DGRS will show higher concentrations of pHVA, reflecting higher levels of central dopaminergic activity. Significance level will be 0.05 and effect sizes will be reported.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
We will include measures of racial identity (centrality), Social Dominance Orientation, and amount of previous contact with different social groups. 

Additionally, we will also include measures of intergroup anxiety and self-efficacy. Composite variables will be created by averaging scores across the scales.

Secondary analyses: 
- We will examine correlations between racial identity centrality and intentions to engage in dialogue. We are specifically interested in seeing whether White Americans with higher racial centrality are different compared to low-identifying Americans, and compared to Latinx Americans. 
- We will examine whether (lower) anxiety and (higher) self-efficacy mediates the relationship between the growth mindset intervention and intentions to engage in dialogue (parallel mediation model).

sample.value: We will stop data collection once N= 420 (210 for each status group) have submitted a response on Prolific Academy. Deviations from this goal are entirely due to the Prolific software and/or to the researcher's budget constraints for participant compensation.

analyses.value:
2 (Between-groups: control vs intervention) x 2 (Within groups: high vs low group status) mixed-designs ANOVA will examine the effects of the growth mindset intervention on intentions to engage in intergroup dialogue activities. 

Planned comparisons: 
-We will examine change in scores between the control and intervention conditions for White participants vs. Latinx participants. We expect the difference (Control-Int) to be significant among White participants, but not for Latinx participants.

outliers.value:
Exclusions:
We will exclude participants who are suspected to have taken the survey too quickly (outliers), which will be assessed through looking at the histogram of duration. We will also exclude participants who do fail screener questions, fail the attention check (e.g., specific questions and/or answering all 1s or 7s on a scale) and participants who indicated they did not find the article believable (e.g., indicated they thought it was fake). 

Finally, we will exclude participants who indicate at the end of the protocol that they do not wish for their data to be used (data will be excluded from analyses even if they meet all other inclusion criteria).

dependent.value:
DV: Dialogue intentions will be measured using the following items:

1a) Intentions to engage in an online dialogue with a participant of another race will be measured using a 1-7 slider scale (1- Not at all interested to 7 - very interested). 

1b) Once the researcher has "connected" them with another participant*, they will have the option to continue on (by clicking Yes) or to skip to the end of the survey (clicking No).

*connection for an online chat with another participant is part of the cover story. Participants will be informed of a technical error with the other "participant's" connection and no online interaction will actually occur.

2a) 1) Intentions to join a dialogue initiative in the future will be measured using a 1-7 slider scale (1- Not at all interested to 7 - very interested). 
2b) They will be asked to specify availability (days and times). We will use # of signups as an index of intentions (with more days/signups being interpreted as stronger intentions).

conditions.value:
Condition: Intervention type (Control vs Growth Mindset intervention). 
- Participants will be randomly assigned to read either an article on left-handedness (control condition- no intervention) or an article that talks about the brain's capacity to synchronize with others while in communication ( growth mindset intervention). Afterwards, they will be given a writing exercise about the article they read. This writing activity serves as an intervention boost.

Condition 2: Group Status (High vs Low). 
- Group status will NOT be assigned. Rather, race will serve as proxy for group status (i.e., High-White Americans vs Low-Latinx Americans). Pilot studies conducted in Fall 2017 and Spring 2018 demonstrated that White Americans perceived themselves as being higher in status than Latinx Americans. On the other hand, Latinx Americans perceived themselves lower in status vis-a-vis White Americans.

hypothesis.value:
Hypothesis 1: A growth mindset intervention will increase individuals' intentions of engaging in an intergroup dialogue (main effect).

Hypothesis 2: The growth mindset intervention will interact with group status: the intervention will be especially effective for high status groups relative to low status groups (interaction).

On the other hand, Latinx Americans perceived themselves lower in status vis-a-vis White Americans.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Hypothesis 1: A growth mindset intervention will increase individuals' intentions of engaging in an intergroup dialogue (main effect).

Hypothesis 2: The growth mindset intervention will interact with group status: the intervention will be especially effective for high status groups relative to low status groups (interaction).
registration_responses.study_type_other: This is a preregistration form for Study 3 of the Growth Mindset and Intergroup Dialogue project
